column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2

#Text=Moheschunder Bannerjee

#Text=Moheschunder Bannerjee ( Bengali : মহেশচন্দ্র বন্দ্যোপাধ্যায় , fl. 1850 ) or Mahesh Chandra Banerjee was a strong chess player from Bengal , many hundred of whose games survive through the writings of John Cochrane , who regularly played Bannerjee between 1848 and 1860 , during Cochrane 's tenure at the Calcutta bar .
#Text=His first name is sometimes misspelled Mohishunder , though Mahescandra is a variant .
#Text=Banerjee is a common Bengali Brahmin surname .
#Text=Moheshchunder , also known as " the Brahmin " , was a player from the mofussil or suburbs of Calcutta .

#Text=He played traditional Indian chess , which in Bengal at the time , pawns did not have the option of moving two squares from the starting row and pawns would promote to the piece of the square reached .
#Text=Also Bengal chess rules did not have castling , but an unchecked king could execute a knight 's move once during a game .
#Text=However , there is little difference in the middlegame and many Indian chess players were very strong tacticians .
#Text=Bannerjee is likely to have transitioned to western rules after contact with Cochrane and other Europeans .
#Text=Among his contributions to mainstream chess is the class of openings now called Indian Defence . [ 1 ]
#Text=Career
#Text=What little is known of Moheschunder comes from articles that John Cochrane , stationed at Calcutta in the 1840s , wrote for the London chess magazines .
#Text=It appears that Cochrane , who had defeated every player in England barring his protégé Howard Staunton , had been searching for some worthy opponents for some time .
#Text=In the autumn of 1848 , a member of the Calcutta Chess club heard of a Brahmin in a village ( mofussil ) who had never been beaten at chess .
#Text=He found an opportunity of meeting him , played him , and lost .
#Text=It was stated that the man , ' Moheschunder Bonnerjee , a Brahmin ' , of about 50 , hardly knew the European rules of chess ; yet his play was presumably under European rules . [ 1 ]
#Text=This club member brought Bannerjee back to Calcutta with him .
#Text=Cochrane played him and won , but was impressed .
#Text=Banerjee was engaged as " a paid attaché " of the Chess Club , where he improved wonderfully .
#Text=In the Chess Player 's Chronicle for 1851 are published some games between Cochrane and Moheschunder ; and " the Brahmin " figures as a player in various collections of games .

#Text=The Indian Defences by P-KKt3 coupled with P-Q3 , or P-QKt3 coupled with P-K3 , were largely taught to European players by the example of Moheschunder and other Indians , to whom the fianchetto developments were a natural legacy from their own game . [ 1 ]
#Text=It is notable that many of Bannerjee 's openings were based on single pawn moves , the " legacy " mentioned by Sergeant , as in the rules of Indian chess .
#Text=Cochrane is quoted in a letter written by a member of the Calcutta Chess Club , appearing in the Chess Player 's Chronicle in 1850 :
#Text=The only player here who has any chance whatever with Mr Cochrane , upon even terms , is a Brahmin of the name of Moheschunder Bonnerjee .
#Text=Of this worthy , Mr Cochrane has himself remarked that he possesses as great a natural talent for chess as any player he ever met with , without one single exception . [ 2 ]
#Text=Games
#Text=Among his recorded games is the first instance of Gruenfeld Defence , more than 60 years before Ernst Grünfeld was to launch it against Alekhine at Vienna , 1922 :

#Text=John Cochrane – Moheschunder Bannerjee , May 1855 1. d4 Nf6 2 . c4 g6 3 . Nc3 d5 4 . e3 Bg7 5 . Nf3 0-0 6 . cxd5 Nxd5 7 . Be2 Nxc3 8 . bxc3 c5 9.0-0 cxd4 10 . cxd4 Nc6 11 . Bb2 Bg4 12 . Rc1 Rc8 13 . Ba3 Qa5 14 . Qb3 Rfe8 15 . Rc5 Qb6 16 . Rb5 Qd8 17 . Ng5 Bxe2 18 . Nxf7 Na5 and White mates in three ( 19 .
#Text=Nh6+ double check Kh8 20 .
#Text=Moheshchunder had a flair for dramatic play evidenced by his sacrifices in this King 's Indian Defence game ( a variation known today as the Four Pawns Attack ) :

#Text=John Cochrane – Moheschunder Bannerjee 1. e4 d6 2 . d4 g6 3 . c4 Bg7 4 . Nc3 Nf6 5 . f4 0-0 6 . Nf3 Bg4 7 . Bd3 ? e5 ! 8 . fxe5 dxe5 9 . d5 Nxe4 ! ? 10 . Nxe4 f5 11 . Neg5 e4 12 . Ne6 exf3 ! 13 . Nxd8 ? ! fxg2 14 . Rg1 Bxd1 15 . Ne6 Bg4 16 . Nxf8 Kxf8 17 . Rxg2 Nd7 18 . Bf4 Nc5 19 . Kd2 Rc8 20 . Kc2 Bf3 21 . Rf2 Nxd3 22 . Kxd3 Be4+ 23 . Ke3 b5 24 . cxb5 Bxd5 25 . Rd2 Bc4 26 . Rad1 Bf6 27 . Bh6+ Kg8 28 . Kf4 Re8 29 . b3 Bxb5 30 . Rc1 Be2 ! 31 . Re1 Re4+ 32 . Kg3 Bh4+ 0 – 1 [ 5 ]
#Text=The origin of the name " Indian Defence "
#Text=Moheshchunder , like other Indian players of the time , favoured fianchettoed openings , trying to control the centre with long-distance pieces rather than occupying it with the pawns .
#Text=Possibly these ideas germinated in an environment of chess rules that did not permit the initial two-square move for pawns .

#Text=The theory behind these openings were developed in recorded chess history much later , but Cochrane introduced the term Indian defence for this class of openings , which has now come to cover the Nimzo-Indian and many other popular openings .

#Text=Fianchettoes appear to have been a favourite style in Indian chess variants , and the Queen 's Indian defence was also a frequent opening for Mir Sultan Khan , who visited England for five years and won the British Chess Championship in 1929 , 1932 and 1933 .
